abstract.text: An object that handles the measurement and display of a single menu item in its encompassing frame.

inlineContent.text: is no longer used to draw menus. Using it does not affect the appearance of your menus.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
An object that defines the user interface of a button or other clickable region of a view.
An object that stores image data in a form that can be readily transferred to the screen.
A user interface element that contains and displays text, scroll, and browser views, in addition to other view subclasses.
An
object is a vertical matrix of
objects to implement the fields.
The
class is used to implement text entry fields in a form. The left part of an
object contains a title. The right part contains an editable text entry field.
An object that handles the measurement and display of a single menu item in its encompassing frame.
Calculates the minimum required width and height of the receiver’s menu item.
Draws the borders and background associated with the receiver’s menu item (if any).
Draws the image associated with the menu item.
Draws the key equivalent associated with the menu item.
Draws a menu item separator.
Draws the state image associated with the menu item.
Draws the title associated with the menu item.
The width of the image associated with the menu item.
Returns the rectangle into which the menu item’s key equivalent should be drawn.
The width of the menu item’s key equivalent string.
The menu item object associated with the cell.
A Boolean value indicating whether the menu item needs to be displayed.
A Boolean value indicating whether the size of the menu needs to be calculated.
Returns the rectangle into which the menu item’s state image should be drawn.
The width of the image used to indicate the state of the menu item.
The integer tag of the selected menu item.
Returns the rectangle into which the menu item’s title should be drawn.
The width of the menu item’s text, measured in points.
An object that represents an OpenGL graphics context, into which all OpenGL calls are rendered.
A subclass of
that is suitable for rendering OpenGL into layers.
An object that provides access to accelerated offscreen rendering.
An object that specifies the types of buffers and other attributes of the OpenGL context.
A view that displays OpenGL content in a view.
The

class defines the visual appearance of pop-up buttons that display pop-up or pull-down menus. Pop-up menus present the user with a set of choices, much the way radio buttons do, but using much less space. Pull-down menus also provide a set of choices but present the information in a slightly different way, usually to provide a set of commands from which the user can choose.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A layer that provides a layer suitable for rendering OpenGL content.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
